snippet.textDisplay: @Daughter of Gaia Actually, you’re incorrect. Have you not heard or BPD rage? They are known for reactivity and out of control/inappropriate anger. Borderlines are more likely to get violent than the general public that is free from serious personality disorders that significantly affect quality of life. And I’m not saying all with BPD are abusive. I’m just being honest. My dad’s second (now ex) wife and my former best friend both have BPD. They were emotionally abusive; one was also physically abusive! This can happen when you have an unstable sense of self, a deep-seated fear of abandonment, are impulsive, get wild mood swings and angry outbursts, are irrational. Just listen to Amber Heard… she acts out in rage; she has angry outbursts and is both emotionally and physically abusive! Then listen to her change her story in court. She’s a blatant liar. Watch her smirk and roll her eyes. She’s manipulative, lacks empathy. She has a real fear of abandonment and an unstable sense of self. She’s  incredibly self-centered, out of touch. If you look into this, you’ll see Live Abuse Free is spot on in her analysis of Amber Hard, who is pretty classic BPD.

If you look into this, you’ll see Live Abuse Free is spot on in her analysis of Amber Hard, who is pretty classic BPD.

snippet.textDisplay:
I’m confused. You bring up borderline personality disorder, how she is displaying traits of it and how they are sometimes violent. But people with BPD are not any more violent than the general public. And later you also say that she’s very manipulative, but people with borderline are not manipulative. They can be perceived as manipulative but they really aren’t. They are just very very unstable. A person with BPD does not have the stability mentally or emotionally to be capable of planing and executing a planned manipulation. People with BPD are just right now. It’s extremely unlikely that anyone with untreated BPD could ever talk about emotional situations and remain calm. The very basis of BPD is instability. Extremely unstable and uncontrollable emotions. From the video when JD is angry, he displays much stronger than anything I have seen from AH. a behavior that could align with BPD.

BPD comes from major and severe childhood trauma and abuse. That is how people develop it. Bringing it up in this situation is very problematic because of the major, major myths and stigma already surrounding it. BPD does not make any one nor does mean someone is a bad person, or abusive or evil or manipulative or violent. BPD means that someone is suffering immensely, and unable to cope with distress and unable to contain their enormous emotions. How those emotions are expressed varies between individuals. It doesn’t make someone violent. Most BPDs aren’t violent, just as most people aren’t violent. These are just normal regular people. Who happens to be very, very sick.

If she is an abuser and if she has BPD those are not results of each other. BPD does not make you an abuser.

snippet.textDisplay: Live Abuse Free This is a serious situation. I do hope that your impressions and presentation of facts serves to find the truth. It’s very difficult for myself as a viewer of these short clips of audio to fully understand what is being said and conveyed between Johnny and Amber. It would be helpful if you would play the clips in their entirety before interjecting your opinion so that we might understand the context. I am a long time fan of Johnny Depp and it is devastating g to think of him as an abuser. On the other hand these are crazy times where powerful and beloved men have been found to be monsters in their private lives. It’s hard to be shocked. I appreciate having someone dissect this situation in a way that helps us understand. I implore you to do in the most straight forward way possible, as this to me is still very confusing to follow. As someone who has not heard or seen past footage, perhaps you can play it in it’s entirety, explain the circumstances, both sides, and break down what you feel is happening. Thank you

snippet.textDisplay: I disagree, he knows he is recording, he is prompting certain things and words to get her to say, yes. snippet.textDisplay:
But people with Borderline Personality disorder will view their target withdrawing even for their own safety as ABANDONMENT.
They confabulate a story in their heads to justify their out of control emotions. They cannot take responsibility. Mental state is of a toddler.
Moreover the "Splitting" rages are in a psychotic state so they often have no memory of their behavior. Anyway in the BPD view it is the victim who is made responsible for the BPD's BS.
